text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonyous questions. 

Career stage: mid (4-7 years of experience)

"I'm looking at job posting for the first marketing hire at a small startup and I'm interested in trying for it, but I'm worried I'm too inexperienced. I have two years as a content manager under my belt, in addition to two years in a PR agency where I was also writing. I guess my question is for people who took on the role of "first marketing hire": When in your career did you make this move and how did you know you were ready? Open to advice from others as well."

Hi All!

I have a question about returning to work after a big lifestyle change. I’ve been working in content marketing in some capacity for about a decade and then really found my groove with it in the last 5 years or so as I started taking on leadership roles as a Creative Director at a start-up, Senior Copywriter in big tech, then a Content Marketing Manager in mid-size tech for about a year.

Well, I got pregnant and had a baby a year ago (yeah!) and made the decision to take a job that allowed for more flexibility in schedule and wasn’t as demanding as big tech. My current role is content marketing-adjacent. I develop training and education for other content marketers, editors, writers, etc., and I still do freelance content marketing.

My question (finally) is if I wanted to pursue content leadership roles again in the next year or two as my lifestyle shifts again, or if the content marketing itch is unbearable, and I want to return sooner, do you think I’ll have to “work my way up” to those content leadership roles I was tracking on before, so to speak? Like I’ll have some time to make up for? Do you think there are some industries that are better for working, first-time moms than others? I’m sure each company is different, but I’m curious if anyone has seen trends.

Thanks!

I’ve been working in content marketing in some capacity for about a decade and then really found my groove with it in the last 5 years or so as I started taking on leadership roles as a Creative Director at a start-up, Senior Copywriter in big tech, then a Content Marketing Manager in mid-size tech for about a year.

text: Having some background in marketing is great, but I think it really matters how comfortable you are with ambiguity and growing the marketing org from scratch. I've worked in a few roles as the first hire (e.g., marketing, community management) - and while I did have some experience under my belt, I found that being able to work with new challenges, learning quickly and applying those learnings, as well as being confident in my choices was almost more important imo.

I've worked in a few roles as the first hire (e.g., marketing, community management) - and while I did have some experience under my belt, I found that being able to work with new challenges, learning quickly and applying those learnings, as well as being confident in my choices was almost more important imo.

text: i did this once, got the job and honestly wasn't very good at it. the role didn't work out for very long but i learned a ton. my advice would be to apply for jobs that you want, regardless of whether you're perfectly qualified (no one ever is anyway!) and many companies want to chat with folks who express interest. you just never know.
